questions.question: What do you think of this dessert? I ......................... it.
questions.description: Like is not normally used in the continuous form.

questions.question: Would you like .................................. with me?
questions.description: Would you like is followed by a to-infinitive.

questions.question: He likes ............................... stray dogs.
questions.description: Like + to infinitive is used to talk about choices and habits.

questions.question: He likes ................................. in the sea.
questions.description: In British English, like + ing form is mainly used to talk about enjoyment. In American English, like + infinitive is more common.

questions.question: Do you mind if I ............................. a little early today?
questions.description: After do you mind, simple present is used in the if-clause.

questions.question: Would you mind if I .......................... a friend along?
questions.description: A simple past tense is used after would you mind.

questions.question: Age brings wisdom but I .............................. stay young and stupid.
questions.description: Would rather shows preference. Prefer is followed by a to-infinitive.

questions.question: He ................................. a singer.
questions.description: The verb marry does not take a preposition.

questions.question: He is .............................. a singer.
questions.description: The preposition to is used after be married.

questions.question: He worked .......................... a bartender for six years.
questions.description: We use as to talk about people's roles.

questions.question: It looks ............................... we are going to run into trouble all over again.
